awards.title: Max van der Stoel Human Rights Award 2010 for Best Master Thesis
awards.description:
In 1995, Tilburg University decided to introduce a Max van der Stoel Human Rights Award for academic publications on human rights in order to draw more attention to this field of study in academic education and research.  Each year, awards are presented to the best Doctoral dissertation and to the best Master Thesis. In 2010, my thesis “Trading Fundamental Human Rights for Security? An Analysis of the European Union‟s Counter-Terrorism Policy” was awarded the Max van der Stoel Human Rights Award for Best Master Thesis.

The jury was composed of the following members.
• Professor Peter Baehr, chairman of the jury, honorary professor of Human Rights at Utrecht University and former director of the Netherlands Institute of Human Rights,
• Professor Stephan Parmentier, professor of criminology and human rights at the Catholic University of Leuven and former vice-president of the Flanders branch of Amnesty International,
• Dr. Marlies Glasius, senior lecturer in International Relations at the Department of Political Science of the University of Amsterdam.

The jury report:

"Shahid's study explores to what extent the European Union has adhered to the fundamental human rights and civil liberties of its citizens when applying several counter-terrorist measures in the last five to ten years.

Shahid has produced a carefully written, well-documented, nicely ordered thesis on a complex subject. She aptly indicates the gaps in the EU legal framework and applies them to concrete situations. She clearly answers her central research question. The subject matter is one of the most crucial concerns relating to human rights in contemporary western societies."

Coordinating the Berkeley LGBTIQ Network along with Ajita Banerjie, Peter Dunne, and Liam Elphick. The Berkeley LGBTIQ Network is a subgroup within the Berkeley Center on Comparative Equality & Anti-Discrimination Law. Our goal for the Network is to bring together as broad a group of scholars, lawyers, and activists as possible – reflecting a wide spectrum of disciplinary, methodological, cultural, socio-political, and geographical perspectives – in the field of LGBTIQ-related issues. We plan to organize online seminars and conferences in this field, as well as work together to publish relevant research. 

For more information on the Network, please do not hesitate to contact me.
